bibl.title: Genevive Wilds v. Territory of Washington. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF GENEVIVE WILDS FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS} 3895 Petition

The undersigned petitioner, Genevive Wilds, of Seattle, King County, Washington, respectfully shows to this Honerable Court that she is imprisoned and restraiend of her liberty by J.S. McBride, City Health Officer of the City of Seattle, and id confined and imprisoned in the County-City Building in Seattle, against her will and protests; that she has not been committed or detained by virtue of any process of any final judgemnt or decree of any compeptent Tribunal, Court or Judge of Civil or Criminal jursdiction or by virtue of any execution, warrant, writ or process of any kind whatsoever; that the cause or pretense of her restraint and impiosnment, according to the best knowledge and belief of petitioner is an order issued by said J.S.McBride Health Officer of the City of Seattle, directing that petitioner be held in restrait and confinement for a period of from one to three months in order that she might receive treatment for a disease which said J.S.McBride alleges and pretends that petitioner is afflicted with; that as a matter of fact, the petitioner is not afflicted with any disease whatsoever, and no reason for holing the petitioner for said treatment xists. That peitioner has not been exposed to any contageous or dangerous or infectious diseasr and there is no danger of petitioner communicating any disease of any kind to the public or to nay persons whith whom she may come in contact.

That said J.S. McBride pretends to have power and authority to hold and imprison petitioner as above set forth under and by virtue of Ordinance No.37928, passed by the City Council
of the City of Seattle in the month of November, 1917; that as a matter of fact, said Ordinance is invalid becasue the provisions thereof are contrary to the constitution of the Uniteed States and constitution and laws of the State of Washington, and becasue no valid cause or reason exists, so far as petitioner is concernd, for exercising any powe such as are pretend to be conferred by said Ordinance.

That petitioner is not permitted to receive visitors of to use the telephone, or talk with her friends or her family except that between the hours of 2 and 4 each day visitors are permitted to talk to petitioner through a wire netting for five minutes at a time; that petitioner is not being properly cared for and does not recive proper food, nor considerate or proper treatment; that petitioner is forced to come in contact with ersons of vicious character and morals, afflicted with various infectious diseases, dangerous to the health of petitioner; that the imprisonment and restrait of petitioner are illegal and contrary to the provisions of the constitution of the United States and petitioner has no adequate remedy, except through a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus may issue directed to the said J.S.McBride, commanding him that he have the body of said petitioner, by him imprisoned and detained, together with a full report and return, setting forth the time, cause and authority of such imprisonmnet and detention, before this Honorable court, and that this petitioner be permitted to then and there offer evidence and testimony in regard to the facts in relation to the detention and imprisonemnt of petitioner, and that this court then and there enter such judgemnt or order as shall be just and equitable under the laws and statutes of the United States and the State of Washington
State of Washington County of Kind} ss.
Genevive Wilds being first duly sworn on oath deposes and says; that she is the petitioner herein; that she has read the foregoign petition knows the contents thereof and belives the same to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 16th day of Febuary, 1918
Eugene A.Childe, Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, resideing at Seattle.
